Agricultural professionals use soil data to optimize crop yields in several ways. Firstly, soil data helps farmers to determine which crops can grow effectively in a particular soil type. Farmers conduct soil analysis, examining the soil's pH, organic matter, and nutrient content, to ascertain the chemical and physical characteristics of the soil. They use these data to determine the necessary fertilizer amendment and crop rotation practices.

Moreover, soil data supports farmers in making informed decisions about irrigation practices. Soil moisture levels influence crop growth, and understanding soil moisture and water-holding capacity helps farmers determine the best irrigation schedules.

Weather data is also essential in determining the optimal time for planting and harvesting crops. Farmers use weather data to check rainfall, temperature, humidity, and wind patterns to estimate crop yields and anticipate weather-related crop failures. Low temperatures, frost, or drought can lead to crop loss or reduced yields. With accurate weather data, farmers can invest in farming practices such as crop insurance or adjust crop species, planting and harvesting schedules accordingly.

At the same time, feeding strategies for livestock require careful monitoring of soil nutrient availability and precipitation. The forage quality monitoring systems producers apply incorporate weather data to plan out the use of supplementary feeding techniques or adjust grazing densities. In situations where hay production is not a viable option, farmers alter the quantities of supplementary protein and mineral supplements to optimize nutrient consumption in livestock. Therefore, agricultural professionals use soil and weather data to optimize crop yields, minimize losses and maximize feeding strategies utilizing the best available data to enhance productivity in their farming practices.
